title: How will 5G affect the speed of one’s smartphone, and will it be noticeable to most users? - Quora

response.answer_text: 5G comes in three flavors, the super slow super low powered flavor that the iPhone doesn’t use. The super fast mmWave one that many cellular carriers are advertising on TV and a “modest improvement” flavor called “sub-6Ghz”. All of them only effect the speed of the cellular network. They only do so if you are in a location that actually has the kind of 5G network in question installed and ready for use by your cell provider (and sometimes you need a specific plan to be allowed to use it). Some 5G phones also ship with 5G turned off because they all use much more battery power to run. The iPhone (and maybe others) turns on 5G (where available) if it thinks you need extra speed, and turns it off when it thinks you don’t (you can also manually set it to “always try 5G”, and “never use 5G”). The mmWave 5G really is fast. It also can’t go through walls very well, and has extremely limited range. Like a few blocks. Think of it as a sort of “super WiFi” that carriers might set up in a urban downtown, a sports arena, or maybe inside an airport. It is as fast as really good WiFi, maybe even twice that fast. If you download music or a movie the little “download circle (or bar)” really will move fast enough that you might wonder why it is there. That is about it. It might make actual web browsing feel slightly faster, but it probably isn’t really noticeable there. It won’t make apps launch faster. It won’t make the graphics sharper. Anything where the phone needs to “think” won’t get faster. Even network things where the server has to think won’t really get faster. Network things where there is congestion anywhere between the server and you won’t feel faster (if you have a one hour 70 mile commute and the last 5 miles of crap road gets replaced with a nice new multi lane paved highway your commute gets slightly faster, but the first 65 miles still suck up most of the time). The sub-6Ghz 5G is a bit better then LTE. Like nowhere near twice as fast. Maybe 20%? Maybe not. In the real world sometimes slower (although I think that is a teething difficulty t-moble is having, not an inherent weakness of 5G). That download ring? It still takes time, just a little less. If it took four minutes to download a song before it isn’t going to be done in 12 seconds like mmWave, it is going to be 3 minutes or so. Sub-6Ghz can punch through walls and get to places people expect cellular coverage. You can expect sub-6Ghz to be “everywhere” over time. Nothing wrong with 5G, it just isn’t going to be earth shattering. My next phone will have 5G, but I’m absolutely not buying it because it has 5G. I’m sure 5G will be a nice little extra. Much like people are happy when the phone’s CPU is a little faster, but they tend not to buy it for that (or at least not just that).

Q1: How will 5G affect the speed of one’s smartphone A1: It can make the online experience much faster for the user, as fast or possibly faster than their experience on their home internet access (WiFi, etc.) Q2: and will it be noticeable to most users A2: When the fastest speeds are available yes it will be easily noticeable to the user, when on the mid-range and low-range services then it can feel no different from today’s service The iPhone 12 was just released and it supports all 5G servicesHigh BandThe is also known as mmWave, and is the band (group of frequencies) that delivers super high speed, the first actual in-use iPhone 12 users in the US are reporting speeds in excess of 2 Gbps, which is many time faster than the speed that most users get on their home networkThe phenomenal speed of 5G high band has a tradeoff of very short rangeMid BandThis is much lower speed than High Band but has reasonable range and is a little bit faster than 4G/LTELow BandOffers the longest distance coverage, possible slightly longer range than 4G/LTE, at speeds that are very similar to 4G, possibly a little bit slower when at the longest range of coverageExtensive use of 5G can make any smartphone run hot, heat makes CPUs run slower (so they don't overheat)On the 2019 and 2020 Android phones, they have gotten so hot that they shit themselves down, and a few reviewers reported that the dropped their Samsung 5G phones on the concrete sidewalk because they were suddenly so hot that they felt their hand was getting burned2020 iPhones have a feature to manage heat from the Qualcomm 5G modem chip, so the phone does not get too hot, switching between 5G bands, and 4G, when necessary to keep the phone temperatures under control so it never gets hot and never shuts down, 5G iPhones will stay online continuously so iPhones will not slow down they will offer normal performance all the time
